;;Rishi Sunak 在 Bletchley Park 人工智能安全峰会闭幕新闻发布会上发表讲话
;

; Rishi Sunak 宣布，最先进的科技公司将首次允许政府审查其人工智能工具，埃隆·马斯克警告称，该技术最终可能取代所有人类工作。

;

;包括 Meta、Google DeepMind 和OpenAI 已同意允许监管机构在向公众发布最新的人工智能产品之前对其进行测试，官方表示此举将减缓开发可与人类竞争的系统的竞赛。

;

;Sunak 在星期四，在;两天之后在布莱切利公园举行的峰会;上，包括世界首富、美国副总统和中国政府高级官员在内的不同群体一致认为人工智能对人类构成了严重风险。

;

;讲话苏纳克在峰会结束时对记者表示：“我相信本次峰会的成就将使天平向有利于人类的方向倾斜。”

;
;

;;相关：;< a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/nov/02/the-great-powers-signed-up-to-sunaks-ai-summit-while-josdling-for-position">;大国签署了苏纳克人工智能峰会——同时争夺位置;

;
;

;总理还宣布国际社会支持受政府间气候变化专门委员会启发成立的专家机构，随后，科技亿万富翁埃隆·马斯克在伦敦市中心的一次谈话中对这些举措表示欢迎，谈话中马斯克描述了他所认为的戏剧性的变化。人类不同的未来。

; ;

;“我们在这里看到了历史上最具破坏性的力量，”他说。 “总有一天，不需要工作。如果你想要工作，就可以找到工作……但人工智能将能够做所有事情。”

;

;马斯克表示，他认为这次峰会在先进人工智能的发展方面实现了有意义的转变。他说：“仅仅拥有洞察力并能够向公众强调所关心的问题就非常有力量。”; ;

;

;苏纳克在峰会结束时表示，与各方达成的协议多个国家和人工智能公司已大大减少了该技术带来的威胁。

;

;然而，他被迫捍卫测试协议的自愿性质，因为他的政府拒绝出台立法来限制人工智能的发展。

;

;他解释说，英国必须比立法时间表允许的速度更快地采取行动，他说：“技术的发展速度如此之快，政府必须确保我们能够跟上。”

;

;他表示，最终“具有约束力的要求”对于人工智能公司来说可能是必要的。

;

;根据在布莱切利公园宣布的协议，“志同道合”的政府和人工智能公司已同意合作进行测试新人工智能模型发布前后的安全性。

;

;支撑 ChatGPT 聊天机器人等工具的大型语言模型将与政府合作进行测试，以应对一系列危险，包括国家安全、安全和社会危害。

;

;此举是在发布;白宫本周发布的行政命令;，要求大型科技公司在其模型上市前向美国政府提交其模型的测试结果。<苏纳克表示，测试将由美国和英国新成立的人工智能安全机构领导，英国机构将自己定位为多边倡议的“全球中心”，但中国不参与其中。

;

;该测试协议得到了欧盟以及美国、英国、日本、法国和德国等10个国家的支持。已同意测试的领先人工智能公司包括谷歌、OpenAI、亚马逊、微软和 Meta。

;

;苏纳克表示，联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯已帮助确保国际社会支持专家小组发布一份“人工智能科学状况”报告。

;

;“这个想法的灵感来自政府间气候变化专门委员会为达成国际科学共识而成立的方式，”苏纳克说。 “在联合国秘书长的支持下，每个国家都承诺提名专家。”

;

;被称为现代人工智能教父之一的 Yoshua Bengio 将主持第一份安全报告的制作。 Bengio 是 ACM 图灵奖（相当于计算机科学领域的诺贝尔奖）的获得者，在人工智能发展的争论中一直是一个突出的谨慎声音。

;

;他是 ;这封信发表于3 月份呼吁“大型”人工智能实验暂停六个月，他支持 5 月份的一份声明，警告人工智能带来的灭绝风险应该与减轻流行病和核灾难带来的社会风险同等重要。周四早些时候，苏纳克在接受记者采访时提出了;核战争与流行病比较;。他说：“开发这项技术的人们自己已经增加了人工智能可能带来的风险，重要的是不要对此危言耸听。”

;

;“关于这个话题存在争议。业内人士本身并不同意，我们也无法确定。

;

;“但有理由相信，它可能会带来像流行病和核战争这样规模的风险，这就是为什么作为领导者，我们有责任采取行动，采取措施保护人民，而这正是我们正在做的事情。”

; ;

;对人工智能的担忧——这个术语是指可以执行通常与智能生物相关的任务的计算机系统——范围从大规模威胁到在选举中制造虚假信息，以逃避控制并威胁人类的先进系统。

;

;总理的宣布是国际人工智能安全峰会第二天紧张外交活动的高潮。

;
; < p>;;相关：;;英国布莱奇利公园人工智能安全峰会的五个要点;

;
;

;英国官员很高兴能够;在峰会开始时发表公报;，由英国、美国、欧盟、中国等28个政府。 “布莱切利宣言”承诺，签署方将共同制定共同的安全标准，官员们将这一过程比作气候危机缔约方峰会。

;

;苏纳克试图将英国定位为开发新能源的世界领导者。周三，美国商务部长吉娜·雷蒙多 (Gina Raimondo) 的一项声明;部分掩盖了;人工智能规则的光芒”，华盛顿一家新的人工智能安全研究所。

;

;英国官员表示，他们希望与美国新的研究所和其他机构密切合作，创建一个由类似组织组成的网络，可以在多边机构的帮助下在世界各地进行测试。测试协议构成了这种合作的框架。

;

;苏纳克在峰会结束时的新闻发布会上发表讲话时表示，他认识到人工智能可能会消除就业机会的担忧，但工人应该;将技术视为“副驾驶” ”;。

;

;“我知道这是人们的焦虑，”他说。 “我们应该更多地将人工智能视为副驾驶，而不是必然会取代某人工作的东西。

;

;“人工智能是一种工具，可以帮助几乎每个人更好、更快、更快地完成工作，这就是我们已经看到的它的部署方式。”

;

;年度珊瑚产卵已开始于周四晚上，潜水员在凯恩斯以东 47 公里的摩尔礁上捕捉到软珊瑚产卵的过程。

;

;随着不同种类的软珊瑚和少数硬珊瑚开始再生过程，数十亿个粉红色的小球爆炸到水中，并在夜间产卵几个小时。

;

;性细胞束破裂，当精子和卵子漂浮在珊瑚海洋流上时，释放精子和卵子相互碰撞，然后落在珊瑚碎石上形成小珊瑚。

;更多壮观的硬珊瑚预计将在周五晚上开始再生过程。

;

;海洋生物学家 Stuart Ireland 在过去十年中每年都会拍摄摩尔礁的产卵过程。

;

;“经过过去六年的强劲增长，摩尔礁的珊瑚覆盖率和多样性非常高，2023 年的产卵反应了这一点，”他说。 “和往年一样，我们观察软珊瑚开始产卵过程，并花了几个小时观察精子和卵子的释放。

;

;“今晚太阳落山后，我们将再次在摩尔礁潜水并期望看到大堡礁开始再生过程的更壮观的硬珊瑚现象。”

;

;Abbi Scott 博士是詹姆斯库克大学的研究员，他正在与旅游经营者合作以了解产卵事件后珊瑚的补充。

;

;她说，正在将瓷砖分布在五个珊瑚礁上，供小珊瑚生长。明年将与珊瑚幼虫扩散模型的数据一起对它们进行分析，以更好地了解幼虫起源的珊瑚礁的连通性。

;

;“这项研究将了解每个研究珊瑚礁的珊瑚补充的相对变化。以及每个珊瑚礁的不同之处，”她说。

;

;“这对于为辅助珊瑚恢复计划提供信息并帮助运营商管理其高价值旅游景点将很有用。”

;

;今年的满月发生在 11 月末。十月，十一月底还会有一次，这可能会导致两个月亮之后分裂产卵。

;;当德里被严重烟雾吞没时，一名男子将衣服挂在栅栏上晾干。
;

;周五，德里的空气质量达到严重水平，浓浓的有毒烟雾笼罩着这座城市，标志着污染季节的开始，污染季节已成为印度首都的年度灾难。

;

;学校关闭，非必要的建筑也被关闭。由于该市的空气质量指数几乎达到 500，这是测量结果的最高值，也是世界卫生组织认为健康限值的 100 倍，因此在德里周围实施了禁令。

;
;

;;相关：;;'在德里我可以看到气候灾难;

;
;

;过去一周，由于邻近的哈里亚纳邦和旁遮普邦烧毁农田的农民人数急剧增加，该市的空气质量不断恶化作物种植季节期间，大风将污染物带入德里，加上气温下降，捕获了颗粒物。

;

;周日，旁遮普邦的农场火灾增加了 740%，超过一天内记录了一千个。该市污染的其他原因包括汽车尾气、建筑以及垃圾处理厂焚烧垃圾。

;

;德里拥有约 3300 万人口，是 ;定期对世界上污染最严重的城市进行排名;。根据芝加哥大学能源政策研究所编制的今年空气质量寿命指数，德里人民由于呼吸的空气质量差，寿命可能会缩短11.9年。

;

;德里医生表示他们开始看到污染对城市居民造成的破坏性影响。 “患有呼吸问题的患者数量有所增加，更多人出现咳嗽、感冒、流泪、眼睛发炎以及呼吸问题。所有年龄段的人都会受到这种影响。德里阿波罗医院的医生尼基尔·莫迪（Nikhil Modi）说：“现在是我们戴口罩、只在需要时才出门的时候了。” ://media.guim.co.uk/44f5fbc1751636cde1b6dd9aded91b12a9037d14/0_143_4353_2610/1000.jpg" alt="一名男子走在新德里印度门附近的卡尔塔维亚小径的草坪上" width="1000" height="600">;

; ; < p>;根据中央污染控制委员会的数据，德里 10 月份的污染水平是 2020 年以来最严重的。

;

;尽管由阿姆阿德米党 (AAP) 领导的德里政府坚称其存在污染问题行动计划中，空气质量急剧下降似乎对每年（通常是在 11 月至 1 月期间）德里居民的生活造成的严重下降影响不大。

;

;AAP 政府为解决污染而采取的方法包括在道路上洒水以减少灰尘，以及建造两座 80 英尺高的“烟雾塔”，每座成本超过 200 万美元，这些措施本应净化空气，但科学家认为基本上没有效果。

;相反，她将其描述为一瞥——尽管是极端的——社会媒体以及极右翼分子不断放大的尖酸刻薄的言论，正在重塑政治。卡格在接受《卫报》采访时警告说，在妇女、少数族裔和有色人种的政治参与方面，这一转变可能会导致数十年来取得的进展倒退。

;

;她的离开让越来越多的芬兰知名女性政治家背弃政治;Sanna Marin; 前往苏格兰;Mhairi Black;。

; <苏格兰前首席大臣尼古拉·斯特金 (Nicola Sturgeon) 在二月份辞职后表示 ;女性政治家的气候不断恶化;，她将当前的环境描述为“比她数十年职业生涯中的任何其他时期都“更加严峻和更具敌意”。

; ;

;“社交媒体为最可怕的虐待女性、厌女症、性别歧视以及对那些把头伸出护栏的女性进行暴力威胁提供了工具，”她在 BBC 的一部纪录片中说道。

;

;Kaag 也赞同这一观点。 “这不是关于我的——忘了我——而是关于它对社会的影响，”卡格说。 “这也影响了我们民主的质量，并且会阻碍有地位的人、有能力的人、妇女、有色人种甚至愿意参与政治生活。那么这对我们未来的民主意味着什么呢？”

;

;Kaag 将她自己在网络仇恨方面的经历追溯到 2017 年，当时有传言称她在经历了数十年的高调之后返回家乡加入政府;国际工作。;“这有点是由一小群人推动的，他们对荷兰部长发生的事情感到愤怒与耶路撒冷的巴勒斯坦人结婚，”她说。她的丈夫 Anis al-Qaq 曾担任巴勒斯坦权力机构副部长和驻瑞士大使 ;共同创立;国际中东和平论坛的工作东方。 “所以那是一个非常小的团体，但它的声音非常大，非常有针对性，而且非常令人讨厌。”

;

;正如她和她的派对;取得了一个又一个的成功 - 卡格于 2022 年成为该国第一位女性财政部长 - 虐待行为不断增加。 “因此，无论是指控、侮辱、恐吓，凡是你能想到的，这都是一个渐强的、永不减弱的渐强，”她说。她的家人常常被卷入其中。去年，一名男子;被当地媒体描述; 一位著名的阴谋论者在家门口手持燃烧的火炬被捕。

; ;

;

;在荷兰 - 2014 年另一位女性 D66 政治家埃尔斯·博斯特 (Els Borst) ;被谋杀;在起草了一项具有里程碑意义的安乐死合法化法律之后——该国内政部长最近的一项研究;发现女性政客;比她们的男同事更有可能面临暴力威胁和攻击。

;

;经常敢于直言不讳的女性卡格说，这些虐待行为发现自己正在抵制隐晦的批评，因为他们试图将自己描绘成受害者。 “在荷兰，你经常被问到：是什么让你认为人们如此恨你？”

;

;她将其描述为一种“羞辱”形式，让许多人对自己受到的虐待保持沉默。 “我认为很多女性仍然觉得自己必须坚持下去。”

;

;她说，卡格希望看到的是加大立法力度来解决网络仇恨问题，让立法者努力解决棘手问题例如隐私和信息自由，以打击人肉搜索、匿名账户和通过算法放大仇恨言论等问题。

;

;“现在说‘哦，不应该这样做’已经太晚了。”这个，”她说。 “有一个非常直言不讳、尖叫的少数人，他们要么危及他人，要么威胁、恐吓，你知道，要么希望他们离开，这样就可以说话了。他们超越了沉默的大多数。”

; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 13:52:02 +0800 KPMG lodges complaint after AI-generated material was used to implicate them in non-existent scandalshttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/nov/03/kpmg-ai-complaint-non-existent-scandal-ai-case-studies-google-bard
;;2023-11-03T05:10:44Z;
;
;;毕马威标志
;

;参议院委员会警告人工智能可能严重破坏了其完整性，之后咨询巨头毕马威针对事实不准确的信息获得议会特权提出正式投诉。

;

;一群学者;has apologised to the big four consultancy firms; after their submission to an inquiry contained false allegations of serious wrongdoing , which were collated by an AI tool and not factchecked.

;

;One academic has claimed responsibility for the errors, generated by the Google Bard AI tool, which produced case studies that never occurred and cited them as examples of why structural reform was needed.

;
    ;
  • ;

    ;;;Sign up for Guardian Australia's free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup;;

    ;
    • ;
;

;The submission accused firms of involvement in scandals that either didn't exist or that they had nothing to do with. It referenced partners being dismissed by firms that had never employed them.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Australian academics apologise for false AI-generated allegations against big four consultancy firms;

;
;

;The inaccurate submission has been attacked by the firms, which believe their reputation has been unfairly tarnished. KPMG's chief executive, Andrew Yates, complained to the parliamentary joint committee on corporations and financial services, which approved and uploaded the document.

;

;“The livelihoods of the more than 10,000 people who work at KPMG can be affected when obviously incorrect information is put on the public record – protected by parliamentary privilege – and reported as fact,” Yates wrote to the committee.

;

;“We are deeply concerned and disappointed that AI has been relied upon, without comprehensive factchecking, for a submission to such an important parliamentary inquiry.

;

;The submission had falsely accused ;KPMG; of being complicit in a “KPMG 7-Eleven wage-theft scandal” that led to the resignation of several partners. It also accused KPMG of auditing the Commonwealth Bank during a financial planning scandal. KPMG never audited the Commonwealth Bank.

;

;In a statement, the committee said the incident had been reported to the Senate clerk and that it “raised important questions” about the use of artificial intelligence.

;

;“Emerging tools within the artificial intelligence space, whilst appearing to reduce workload, may present serious risks to the integrity and accuracy of work if they are not adequately understood or applied in combination with detailed oversight and rigorous factchecking,” the committee's statement said.

;

;The committee said that when used incorrectly, tools like Google Bard were capable of “seriously undermining the integrity of submissions and the committee process”.

;

;“Ultimately, it is the role of the committee, throughout its inquiry and the right of reply offered to those referenced within submissions, to appropriately weigh the evidence provided based on its truthfulness and accuracy,” the statement said.

;

;In a letter to the Senate, emeritus professor James Guthrie claimed responsibility for the error, excusing the other academics.

;

;“Given that the use of AI has largely led to these inaccuracies, the entire authorship team sincerely apologises to the committee and the named Big Four partnerships in those parts of the two submissions that used and referenced the Google Bard Large Language model generator,” Guthrie said in the letter.

;

;The Sydney University academic Jane Andrew, who was not responsible for the AI research but did contribute to the submission, was a co-author of a 2022 article in the journal Critical Perspectives on Accounting, entitled: “;The perils of artificial intelligence in academic publishing;”.

;

;“We are concerned particularly with the gradual removal of human involvement in journal editor and reviewer roles, as artificial intelligence and automated expert systems become increasingly influential across a range of tasks and judgments historically carried out and performed by people,” the journal article said.

;

;A University of Sydney spokesperson noted Guthrie had taken full responsibility for the use of AI and said Andrew was not given an opportunity to review the submission.

;

;“She did not have a role in reviewing the submission before it was sent, and would have objected to the inclusion of all parts produced by Bard AI if she'd had the opportunity to do so,” the spokesperson said.

;
;

;;Related: ;;The Big Four firms are incapable of unwinding their own deep-seated conflicts | Ian Gow and Stuart Kells;

;
;

;Deloitte also complained to the committee about the submission. The firm's general counsel, Tala Bennett, said “it is disappointing that this has occurred, and we look forward to understanding the committee's approach to correcting this information”.

;

;Guthrie said the factual errors were “regrettable” but insisted “our substantive arguments and our recommendations for reform remain important to ensure a sustainable sector built on shared community values”.

; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 13:52:02 +0800 Sea-lice outbreak on Icelandic salmon farm a ‘welfare disaster’, footage showshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/03/sea-lice-outbreak-icelandic-salmon-farm-welfare-disaster-footage-shows
;;2023-11-03T05:00:00Z;
;
;;Aerial shot of two ships next to a large cage
;

;Images of severely diseased, dead and dying salmon at an Icelandic fish farm, obtained by the Guardian, have been described by one veterinary expert as an “animal welfare disaster” on a scale never previously seen.

;

;The drone footage, shot last week over an open-pen sea cage in the country's remote Westfjords region, shows salmon suffering from such a severe ;infestation of sea lice; that huge numbers of the fish are having to be prematurely slaughtered.

;

;Up to 12 pens are believed to be affected by the parasites, which contained about a million fish last month, although the exact numbers have not been confirmed. A specialised vessel, the Hordafor III, sent from Norway to euthanise the fish, is seen in the footage.

;

;The parasite, a crustacean known as salmon lice – ;Lepeophtheirus salmonis; – feeds on the salmon's skin, causing open sores that stress and weaken the salmon's immune system. In extreme cases, it can cause mass deaths.

;

;Berglind Helga Bergsdóttir, a specialist in fish diseases at ;MAST;, the Icelandic food and veterinary authority, said that such a high infestation of lice had never been seen before in Iceland.

;

;“The lesions don't get much worse than this,” said Bergsdóttir. The wounds were worsened by bacteria which make them deeper and bigger, she said. “What has surprised everyone here is how quickly it happened.”

; ;

;The incident comes at a difficult time for the open-pen salmon-farming industry in Iceland.

;

;In August, ;the escape of 3,500 salmon from a farm owned by Arctic Fish;, one of two companies with pens in Tálknafjörður, the site of the current lice outbreak, caused outrage among environmentalists and led to an investigation by Icelandic police.

;

;Arctic Fish is one of the country's largest salmon-farming companies, owned by Norwegian-based Mowi, the world's largest salmon producer. The escape sparked a ;protest by Björk.; The Icelandic singer is releasing ;a song with the Catalan star Rosalía; to benefit activists fighting salmon farms, which she claimed were having a “devastating effect” on Icelandic wildlife.

;

;Mast stressed that the two companies owning sea pens at Tálknafjörður – Artic Fish and Arnarlax – had taken the decision to humanely slaughter the affected salmon, which are not permitted to be used for human consumption.

;

;Arnarlax said that not all the pens were necessarily affected. Once slaughtered, the fish would be processed for animal feed, it said.

;

;Mast is investigating the cause of the incident, Bergsdóttir said, which escalated after the authority gave permission for the outbreak to be treated with insecticide.

;

;Worryingly, the insecticide did not kill all of the lice and the infestation grew, Bergsdóttir said. “In two to three weeks, there were huge increases in lice.”

; ;

;One theory the agency would investigate is whether the lice had mutated, she said. “We know lice are very adaptable and one method they use is mutation, especially with the drugs.”

;

;Trygve Poppe, a salmon expert and former professor of fish health at the Norwegian school of veterinary science, said: “It is the worst I have ever seen, both in the extent of the lesions and the number of fish affected. It's an animal welfare disaster.”

;

;Infestations of salmon lice were increasing across the industry, in Norway, Scotland and Iceland, he said. This year, eight open-pen farms were given permission to use insecticides including emamectin, azamethiphos and deltamethrin.

;

;Lice cause pain and blood loss in the fish, Poppe said. “You can see from the pink heads, the skin barrier between the fish and the water is completely gone,” he added. “The fish are leaking, causing a loss of balance. Most of the fish are just moribund. We are seeing the terminal stages of their lives.”

;

;Veiga Grétarsdóttir, a kayaker and activist who took the drone footage of the disposal of the salmon at Tálknafjörður last week, said she was shocked by the condition of the fish.

;

;“I don't think I saw one healthy fish,” said Grétarsdóttir, who collaborates with the Icelandic Wildlife Fund. “They were moving very slowly, like zombie fish; dead but moving.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;'We can carry on for ever': meet Iceland's last whale hunter;

;
;

;A spokesperson for Arctic Fish said: “Due to increased sea-lice pressure, Arctic Fish has decided to take out fish at Tálknafjörður. Increased sea-lice pressure in the area has unfortunately made it necessary.

;

;“The situation escalated very fast and the company is doing all it can to take out the fish as soon as possible.”

;

;He said that “the process of having the correct measures against lice approved and applied is far too bureaucratic”, which led to escalating numbers of lice.

;

;“Arctic Fish acknowledges the responsibility of the welfare of our fish but we also see an urgent need for an adjusted framework where the bureaucracy isn't compromising the welfare [of the fish].”

;

;A spokesperson for Arnarlax said it had experienced higher pressure from lice than usual and had taken the decision to extract some salmon to ensure the “good biological status” of the remaining fish.

;

;He said the company, which now used a non-chemical method of delousing, had not lost 12 pens, but did not elaborate on the numbers destroyed. He confirmed that, after culling, the fish would be turned into animal feed.

; Fri, 03 Nov 2023 13:52:02 +0800 Putin criticised as he withdraws Russia’s ratification of nuclear test ban treatyhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/03/vladimir-putin-withdraws-russia-ratification-nuclear-test-ban-treaty-criticism
;;2023-11-03T02:21:01Z;
;
;;Russian president Vladimir Putin attends a nuclear attack drill via video conference in Moscow on October 25, 2023.
;

;Vladimir Putin has signed into law Russia withdrawing its ratification of the global treaty banning nuclear weapons tests, a step condemned by the US and the organisation that promotes adherence to the landmark arms control pact.

;

;The move, though expected, is evidence of the deep chill between the United States and Russia over the war in Ukraine, whose ties are at their lowest level since the 1962 Cuban missile crisis and what Moscow casts as Washington's attempts to stymie the emergence of a new multipolar world order.

;

;Washington expressed deep concern about Russia's decision, saying it was a step in the wrong direction. “Russia's action will only serve to set back confidence in the international arms control regime,” US secretary of state Antony Blinken said in a statement.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Vladimir Putin escalates nuclear rhetoric with threat to resume testing;

;
;

;Moscow said its deratification of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) was merely designed to bring Russia into line with the US, which signed but never ratified the treaty. The US signed the CTBT in 1996 but the Senate did not ratify it. Successive US administrations however have observed a moratorium on testing nuclear weapons.

;

;Russia will not resume nuclear testing unless Washington does, said Russian diplomats.

;

;Speaking in Sochi a month ago, the Russian president made several references to nuclear weapons. He said he was “not ready to say now whether we really need or don't need to conduct tests”, adding “As a rule, experts say, with a new weapon – you need to ;make sure that the special warhead will work; without failures.”

;

;Since the all-out invasion of ;Ukraine; in February 2022, Putin and other Russian officials have frequently drawn attention to the country's nuclear arsenal, the biggest in the world, in an attempt to deter other countries from helping Ukraine resist the invasion.

;

;Any Russian nuclear test would be the first since 1990, the last conducted by the Soviet Union. Renewed testing by a nuclear superpower would undo one of the principal advances in non-proliferation since the cold war.

;

;Robert Floyd, head of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty Organization, whose job is to promote recognition of the treaty and build up its verification regime to ensure no nuclear tests go undetected, condemned Russia's step.

;

;“Today's decision by the Russian Federation to revoke its ratification of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty is very disappointing and deeply regrettable,” Floyd, who had tried to lobby senior Russian officials to get them to change their mind, said.

;

;The treaty established a global network of observation posts that can detect the sound, shock waves or radioactive fallout from a nuclear explosion.

;

;Post-Soviet Russia has not carried out a nuclear test. No country except North Korea has conducted a test involving a nuclear explosion this century.

;

;Andrey Baklitskiy, senior researcher at the United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research, said last month that Russia's deratification of the CTBT was part of a “slippery slope” towards resuming testing. It is part of a disturbing trend in recent years that has seen arms control pacts scrapped or suspended, he said.

;

;“We don't know what steps will follow and when, but we know where this road ends. And we don't want to go there,” he said.

;

;Putin's approval of the de-ratification law was posted on a government website which said the decision took immediate effect. Russia's parliament has already approved the step.

;

;;With Reuters;
